questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following are transmitted biologically by invertebrate vectors?
questions.explanation:
Metazoonoses are a type of zoonoses where the infective agents are transmitted by invertebrate 
vectors. They multiply and develop within the invertebrates (extrinsic incubation period) before 
transmission to a vertebrate host. A zoonosis is any disease or infection that is naturally transmissible from vertebrate animals to 
humans. They can be classified based on their reservoir hosts into: • Anthropozoonoses - transmitted from lower vertebrates to man • Zooanthroponoses - transmitted from man to lower vertebrates • Amphixenoses - may be transmitted in either direction They can also be classified based on the life cycle of the infecting agent: Category

questions.question:
Question 2: Multiple members of the same community presented with sudden-onset fever, chills, and 
painful inguinal swellings as shown below. Further questioning leads to the identification of a 
rat infestation in the locality. Which of the following is the likely source of transmission of 
this disease?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and image showing buboes are suggestive of bubonic plague. It is 
transmitted by the bite of the infected rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis. Rodents, including rats, are 
the reservoirs of infection. On the other hand, the pneumonic plague spreads from man to man by droplet infection. 295 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which of the following indices is the best determinant of a potential plague outbreak?
questions.explanation:
Cheopis index is the best determinant of potential plague outbreaks. If this index is > 1, it 
indicates there is a high likelihood of an outbreak.

questions.question: Question 4: All of the following are causes of different types of typhus except:
questions.explanation: R.rickettsii causes Rocky Mountain spotted fever. It is a type of spotted fever, not typhus. *Note:- Orientia tsutsugamushi was previously known as Rickettsia tsutsugamushi.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following rickettsial diseases is correctly matched with their respective vectors?
questions.explanation:
Endemic typhus is caused by the bite of an infective flea. This condition, also called murine typhus or flea-borne typhus, is caused by Rickettsia typhi. Rats 
serve as reservoirs. The incubation period is 1–2 weeks. The Weil Felix reaction is positive in 
2nd week. The drug of choice is tetracycline. Rodent control is most important and is best done by BHC and 
malathion.

questions.question:
Question 6: A 38-year-old woman is being evaluated for fever and rash. All of the following can be 
included in the differential except:
questions.explanation:
Rashes and local lesions are not a feature of Q-fever. It is caused by Coxiella burnetii. The mode of transmission is the inhalation of infected dust, entry 
through abrasions, or ingestion of contaminated milk. Rarely, ticks can be involved in 
transmission. The incubation period is 2 to 3 weeks. The drug of choice is prolonged treatment with doxycycline. Pasteurization is advised to inactivate 
the causative agent.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following is false about scrub typhus?

options.b: Adult mite feeds on vertebral host

questions.explanation:
Both adult and nymphal stages of the mite are free-living in nature. They do not feed on the 
vertebral host. Scrub typhus is the most widespread rickettsial disease. It is caused by Orientia 
tsutsugamushi (previously known as Rickettsia tsutsugamushi) and transmitted by the bite of 
trombiculid mite. The incubation period is 10-12 days. It presents with a typical eschar at the bite site. It is diagnosed by the Weil Felix reaction, which is 
strongly positive with proteus strain OXK. It is treated by tetracyclines. 296 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following are the causative agent and vector of epidemic typhus respectively?
questions.explanation:
The causative agent of epidemic typhus is Rickettsia prowazekii and the vector is a louse. The incubation period is 10 to 14 days. Brill-Zinsser disease refers to the recurrent form of 
epidemic typhus.

questions.question:
Question 9: A patient presents with fever for 1 week, with abdominal distension, loss of appetite, and 
lymphadenopathy. There is a poor response to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is 
negative but rk39 is positive. Which drug can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. This patient should be managed with 
liposomal amphotericin B. This condition causes fever with rigor and chills associated with splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. 
Though lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, it is rare in India. It is diagnosed by ELISA, indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT), and rk39 which 
detects antibodies to Leishmania donovani. The treatment is as follows: • In most endemic regions: • Drug of choice - pentavalent antimonial (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate) • If it fails or is unavailable - amphotericin B • In India and Mediterranian countries, the drug of choice is liposomal AmB. • Other drugs - paromomycin and miltefosine Option B: Fluconazole is an antifungal and is not useful in visceral leishmaniasis Option C: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA and related infections. Option D: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is not true about Leishmania?

options.b: Extrinsic incubation period of kala-azar is 4 to 25 days
options.d: Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis is caused by L. donovani

questions.explanation:
Leishmania is an intracellular parasite in the macrophages. The vector is Phlebotomus (sandfly). Man is the reservoir in the Indian kala-azar. The incubation 
period is 10 days to 2 years, whereas the extrinsic incubation period is 4 to 25 days. The following 
conditions are caused by Leishmania: • Visceral leishmaniasis or kala-azar – L. donovani • Cutaneous leishmaniasis or oriental sore – L. tropica • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis - L. braziliensis • Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis - L. donovani 297 
Sold by @itachibot The image below is a microscopic image of the LD body. According to the NVBDCP, the management is as follows: • First-line - single-dose liposomal amphotericin B (10 mg/kg IV infusion) • Alternate - paromomycin + miltefosine for 10 days Monotherapy with antimonials (sodium stibogluconate) is no longer recommended due to 
resistance and toxicity. Synthetic pyrethroid is used for indoor residual spraying in all the 
endemic areas.

questions.question: Question 11: Kala-Azar is endemic in all these areas except:
questions.explanation: Kala-Azar is not endemic in Assam. It is endemic in the following states in 54 districts: • Uttar Pradesh • West Bengal • Bihar • Jharkhand
